L.I BERA L CLUB

Since the time of the famed
Baron l\liinchausen the technique
of story telling has become a lost
art. Like the secrets of the Sphinx
and the pyramids, the mystic
magic of the Ancient Chaldeans,
and the necromancy of Merlin, it
has perished with the men who
knew it, and ·m odern civilization
for all its progres and advancement mourns an art which it has
been unable to rediscover.

TOPIC WILL BE
SHORE LYNCHINGS

Bernard Ades, reputed to be
one of Baltimores most outstanding labor lawyers, is scheduled to
address the Liberal Club meeting
at Levering Hall on Friday at 1
P. M. The topic will be '·Law Enforcement on the Eastern Shore."
Mr. Ades, who has been attorney for the International
Labor Defense League, will describe the conditions as to the
lynchings which have recently occured on the Shore.
Cites Williams Case

"The only difference between
the \Villiams lynching and many
other recent hangings is that a
trial was overlooked," Counsellor
Ades stated . .
The main purpose of the International Labor Defense League is
to take up the defense of classwar victims. All attacks or trials
of laborers and Negroes are investigated. This defense has sent
lawyers to 90 per cent of all the
labor trials in the United States.
l\lr. Ades is said to be greatly in
accord with this cause.
Comments On Mooney

Commenting on the Mooney
Case, Mr. Ades is certain that
Mooney is another of th~ many
class-war victims.
Early this
year Mooney asked the International Labor Defense to take
his case. They have done this by
stirring up mass protests, and
encouraging the sending of letters
to Governor Rolf of California.
This mass pressure a:ll over the
country has made most of the
officials in favor of liheration, it
was said. Mr. Ades believes that
Rolf woul anti-Mooney. As a consequence,
Mayor Walker of New York has
gone to California hoping to break
1.his sentiment and thus free
Mooney and save Rolf's political
career.
0

Is Hopkins Graduate

Mr. Bei:nard Ades, who was
born in Baltimore, is an alumnus
of the Baltimore City College and
also of Hopkins where he received a B. S. degree in economics. He later studied law at
the University of Maryland.

FOUR SENIORS
ARE APPOINTED
TO JUNE WEEK

Onker "

Class Dues

Announcement of the appointment of four members of the 1932
June Week Committee was made
last week by Walter F. Kneip,
chairman of the group.
The four men are: r. Cyrus Gutman, treasurer; Ronald Levy, A.
E. Quick, and Edwin Dukehart.
Later appointment of a Junior
selected by the president of the
Junior Class will be determined
\vithin the next month, it is expected. William Weitzel, as president oi the Senior Class, is exofficio member of the committee.
Lacrosse To Be Featured
In outlining the probable pro-

gram of the committee for the
June Week events, Kneip stated
that efforts are being made to arrange for a special lacrosse game
feature, wl1,ich is always included. The ~oming of the Olympic playoffs during that time
should add a great deal of interest to this phase of the festivity.
In order to achieve a more interesting set of attractions, it was
declared, a great deal will depend
upon the payment of Senior Class
dues, part of which finance the
committee. Those who fail to pay
dues will have their tickets for
the occasion withheld.
Limited Membership

The committee is limited in
membership chiefly in order to
naintain effectiveness. Last year's
committee, led by John Yellott,
was composed of eleven men, but
it was believed that the inclusion of too larges a number tended to make it unwieldy.
It is expected that the attendance to the activities will be restricted to Hopkins students and
Alumni and their escorts.
Last Year's Attractions

Special attractions on last
year's program were the importation of Guy Lombardo and his
Royal Canadians for the Senior
Ball, and the Cabaret Party at
Levering Hall.
Early in the spring, a chairman
from the Junior Class will be appointed to lead the 1933 June
Week Committee. The man is
appointed by the Junior Class
president and is usually a member
of the Cotillon Board.

Come To School
Slogan Given Wide Publicity BJ
University of Oklahoma; Head
Explains Why
(From N. S. F. A.)

The University of Oklahoma
recently gave wide publicity to
the slogan-"Work First, Earn
Some Money-Then Come to
School." The president of the
University explained the slogan
was adopted beca.use, "we feel
students who work cannot get
the m.ost out of college when
most of his or her time is taken
up out of school."

Hitler Aqstrian
Hitler was born in Austria.
Disappointed hopes caused by the
early death of his father, acord·
ing to Dr. Mattern, led to much
of the radicalism of the man today. He was attracted to Germany by the greater prevalance
of national feeling there. The
interesting fact was disclosed
that, at present, Hitler is a man
without a country-having ·lost
his Austrian citizenship during the
war, and never having become a
citizen of Germany.
He first sprang into prominence
when he took an active part in
surpressing
the
communistic
movement in Bavaria. Later he
was one of the principal participants in a plot to take over the
government of Germany; plot
that failed, and resulted in Hitler
being sentenced to prison for a
period of five years.
Released From Prison

months, and took up his present
work as leader of the National
Socialist Party. In this connection Dr. Mattern made the statement that he considered Hitler as

case, or at least one on the border
line. He stressed the fact that
Hitler talks too much, boasts too
much, as well as promising and
attacking too much. He quoted
a remar~ of the party leader,

TOPIC WILL BE
SHORE LYNCHINGS

Bernard Ades, reputed to be
one of Baltimores most outstanding labor lawyers, is scheduled to
address the Liberal Club meeting
at Levering Hall on Friday at 1
P. M. The topic will be '·Law Enforcement on the Eastern Shore."
Mr. Ades, who has been attorney for the International
Labor Defense League, will describe the conditions as to the
lynchings which have recently occured on the Shore.
Cites Williams Case

"The only difference between
the \Villiams lynching and many
other recent hangings is that a
trial was overlooked," Counsellor
Ades stated . .
The main purpose of the International Labor Defense League is
to take up the defense of classwar victims. All attacks or trials
of laborers and Negroes are investigated. This defense has sent
lawyers to 90 per cent of all the
labor trials in the United States.
l\lr. Ades is said to be greatly in
accord with this cause.
Comments On Mooney

Commenting on the Mooney
Case, Mr. Ades is certain that
Mooney is another of th~ many
class-war victims.
Early this
year Mooney asked the International Labor Defense to take
his case. They have done this by
stirring up mass protests, and
encouraging the sending of letters
to Governor Rolf of California.
This mass pressure a:ll over the
country has made most of the
officials in favor of liheration, it
was said. Mr. Ades believes that
Rolf woul anti-Mooney. As a consequence,
Mayor Walker of New York has
gone to California hoping to break
1.his sentiment and thus free
Mooney and save Rolf's political
career.
0

Is Hopkins Graduate

Mr. Bei:nard Ades, who was
born in Baltimore, is an alumnus
of the Baltimore City College and
also of Hopkins where he received a B. S. degree in economics. He later studied law at
the University of Maryland.

FOUR SENIORS
ARE APPOINTED
TO JUNE WEEK

Onker "

Class Dues

Announcement of the appointment of four members of the 1932
June Week Committee was made
last week by Walter F. Kneip,
chairman of the group.
The four men are: r. Cyrus Gutman, treasurer; Ronald Levy, A.
E. Quick, and Edwin Dukehart.
Later appointment of a Junior
selected by the president of the
Junior Class will be determined
\vithin the next month, it is expected. William Weitzel, as president oi the Senior Class, is exofficio member of the committee.
Lacrosse To Be Featured
In outlining the probable pro-

gram of the committee for the
June Week events, Kneip stated
that efforts are being made to arrange for a special lacrosse game
feature, wl1,ich is always included. The ~oming of the Olympic playoffs during that time
should add a great deal of interest to this phase of the festivity.
In order to achieve a more interesting set of attractions, it was
declared, a great deal will depend
upon the payment of Senior Class
dues, part of which finance the
committee. Those who fail to pay
dues will have their tickets for
the occasion withheld.
Limited Membership

The committee is limited in
membership chiefly in order to
naintain effectiveness. Last year's
committee, led by John Yellott,
was composed of eleven men, but
it was believed that the inclusion of too larges a number tended to make it unwieldy.
It is expected that the attendance to the activities will be restricted to Hopkins students and
Alumni and their escorts.
Last Year's Attractions

Special attractions on last
year's program were the importation of Guy Lombardo and his
Royal Canadians for the Senior
Ball, and the Cabaret Party at
Levering Hall.
Early in the spring, a chairman
from the Junior Class will be appointed to lead the 1933 June
Week Committee. The man is
appointed by the Junior Class
president and is usually a member
of the Cotillon Board.

up out of school."

A chaotic condition of political
affairs in presept day Germany
was painted by the speaker. The
existence of twelve or more parties makes intelligent legislation
an impossibility, according to Dr.
Mattern, and the cabinet must
carry through all important legislative measures.
In addition to the .a bove hindrances, the country, at the present time, is laboring under other
staggering burdens. Among those
cited were the· huge reparation

'Dr. Mattern stressed the fact
that in considering the present
state of affairs in Germany and
the National Socialist party, Hitler's personality must be taken
into account.
Hitler Aqstrian
Hitler was born in Austria.
Disappointed hopes caused by the
early death of his father, acord·
ing to Dr. Mattern, led to much
of the radicalism of the man today. He was attracted to Germany by the greater prevalance
of national feeling there. The
interesting fact was disclosed
that, at present, Hitler is a man
without a country-having ·lost
his Austrian citizenship during the
war, and never having become a
citizen of Germany.
He first sprang into prominence
when he took an active part in
surpressing
the
communistic
movement in Bavaria. Later he
was one of the principal participants in a plot to take over the
government of Germany; plot
that failed, and resulted in Hitler
being sentenced to prison for a
period of five years.
Released From Prison
He obtained release in six
months, and took up his present
work as leader of the National
Socialist Party. In this connection Dr. Mattern made the statement that he considered Hitler as
more or less · of a pathological
case, or at least one on the border
line. He stressed the fact that
Hitler talks too much, boasts too
much, as well as promising and
attacking too much. He quoted
a remar~ of the party leader,
made when the subject of a forceful seizure of the present government was brought up. Hitler at
that time said: "We need not
march on Berlin, when we are
